docs.lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1996, I accompanied Madeleine K. Albright, then the United States Ambassador to the United Nations, on a trip to the war zones of Africa. During the last stop, in Rwanda, she asked her staff to pose for a picture outside her Air Force 737. The group included a Greek-American, a Czech-American, Jewish Americans, black Americans and white Americans. There were Air Force crewmen from small towns and diplomats from Ivy League colleges, and they were all standing there shoulder to shoulder. As I watched the Rwandan ground crew curiously watching the picture-taking, I couldn't help wondering what they were making of this scene, which represented America at its best: the spirit of community, the melting pot, the willingness to help faraway strangers in need and, most important, a concept of citizenship based on allegiance to an idea rather than to a tribe. As a picture, it represented everything that Rwanda was not.

headline.main: A Manifesto for the Fast World

docs.abstract: Thomas L Friedman article holds United States must accept new role as enforcer of emerging global order; cites its responsibility for maintaining global institutions and stabilizing international system that benefits US more than any other nation; deplores those in Congress who want international respect and benefits of being American without any of accompanying sacrifices and responsibilities; photos; diagram (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Nassau County officials reworked a poorly received plan to close a cumulative budget deficit that is approaching $300 million, the county's bonds were downgraded last week by one Wall Street rating agency, and two others repeated earlier warnings that they were watching to see if Nassau was moving too slowly in closing the gap. After hearing details of County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta's plan, which included new taxes and user fees, modest spending cuts and one-time revenues, Fitch IBCA responded on Monday by lowering its rating of Nassau's bonds a notch to A-minus. The change was the first by a credit-rating agency since $60 million in cost overruns were reported in the county's health insurance plan in January.
docs.abstract: Fitch IBCA lowers rating of Nassau County bonds to A-minus; Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Services repeat earlier warnings that Nassau must move to close cumulative budget deficit (S)
docs.snippet: As Nassau County officials reworked a poorly received plan to close a cumulative budget deficit that is approaching $300 million, the county's bonds were downgraded last week by one Wall Street rating agency, and two others repeated earlier warnings...

docs.lead_paragraph: William F. Galvin, the low-profile Massachusetts Secretary of State, is normally more even-tempered. But he just got too outraged, he says, by the hundreds of phone calls his office was getting from elderly people suddenly struggling to afford their prescription medicine. So today, Mr. Galvin, who as Secretary of State has the power to regulate corporations, held an informal hearing of staff members and representatives of health maintenance organizations as part of an unusual political salvo against H.M.O.'s: he called for public comment on whether a handful of Massachusetts H.M.O.'s deserved to retain their nonprofit status. And he said he would pursue more formal legal proceedings that could strip them of their nonprofit status, and perhaps the tax exemptions that come with it.

headline.main: Elderly Find a Champion on Drug Cutbacks

docs.abstract: Massachusetts Sec of State William F Galvin holds informal hearing on HMO's that are eliminating or sharply curtailing payments for expensive drugs taken by many elderly patients; Galvin also threatens legal action to strip HMO's of nonprofit status; his photo; complaints stem from 1997 Federal law barring states from requiring HMO's to offer option of full-drug coverage, as Massachusetts had done; industry claims majority of seniors benefit under new regime; paradox is that Massachusetts HMO's are ranked among nation's best (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For the employees and the estimated 50,000 remaining policyholders who are the forlorn rear guard in the last days of the insolvent HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, these are hectic days of rage and anxiety. Fran Rosenfeld, a cancer patient who has been with HIP most of her life, has been going to state-organized health fairs in search of a new insurance carrier but has found herself more confused than enlightened by the array of choices. And when she has gone to the New Brunswick HIP center for her final treatments and examinations, she has seen little there to calm her. Instead, she has witnessed ''mass confusion'' as beleaguered HIP workers try to cope with the thousands of requests for copies of medical records or for final appointments.

headline.main: Only Days to Shutdown, 50,000 Patients Are Still Clinging to HIP

docs.abstract: HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, insolvent and set to close down, still has estimated 50,000 policyholders who have not changed to new plan; most are elderly and are confused at losing familiar, convenient services; medical professionals have set up new practices; mental health providers continue therapy sessions, although they have yet to be approved by alternative HMO's (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Amid reports of deaths and serious liver damage caused by the diabetes drug Rezulin, a panel of scientific experts today recommended that the Government place stricter limits on the use of the drug, and urged that patients take it only when other therapies have failed. In a series of votes, the committee stopped short of recommending that the drug be withdrawn from the market, as some consumer safety advocates had urged. Instead, the panel told the Food and Drug Administration that Rezulin, which is used by about 750,000 Americans, should not be used on its own unless the label is changed to warn patients that it carries very grave risks.

headline.main: Stricter Rules Are Urged On Use of a Diabetes Drug

docs.abstract: Scientific panel recommends that FDA place stricter limits on diabetes drug Rezulin, in view of reports of deaths and serious liver damage; stops short of calling for removal from market as some consumer safety advocates urge, but say Rezulin should not be used alone unless label is changed to warn patients of very grave risks; benefits of Rezulin when used with other drugs may outweigh risks (M)
docs.snippet: Amid reports of deaths and serious liver damage caused by the diabetes drug Rezulin, a panel of scientific experts today recommended that the Government place stricter limits on the use of the drug, and urged that patients take it only when other...

docs.lead_paragraph: He has been the head of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. for less than a week, but Denis M. Hughes is already planning an offensive against Gov. George E. Pataki's budget. At the prodding of Mr. Hughes, whom it elected Tuesday as its president, the state labor federation plans to have more than 2,500 union members distribute leaflets on Tuesday in New York City, Buffalo, Syracuse and seven other cities to protest Mr. Pataki's proposals to cut spending on Medicaid, road repairs and college tuition assistance.

headline.main: An Assertive Start for New Labor Chief

docs.abstract: Denis M Hughes, new president of New York AFL-CIO, begins by mapping offensive against Gov George Pataki's proposed budget cuts; Hughes vows more aggressive union stance; photo; statement comes amid criticism of Brian McLaughlin, president of New York City Central Labor Council (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, filming equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the production, marketing and exhibition of moving images. Monk's Cafe, the set of the diner where much of ''Seinfeld'' took place, includes costumes and scripts. Through August. ''Serene Intensity: The Films of Ernie Gehr,'' a retrospective of works by the American avant-garde filmmaker, runs through Sunday. Tomorrow: ''Still'' (1969-71), at 2 P.M.; Sunday afternoon: at 2, three shorts; at 3:30, five shorts; at 4:30, three shorts. In Tut's Fever Movie Palace, screenings of ''Flash Gordon Conquers the Universe,'' a 12-part series (1939-40) with a new segment each week, through next Friday. Show times: Tuesdays through Fridays at 1, 2:30 and 4 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays at 1, 2, 3 and 4 P.M. ''Computer Space '98'' is an exhibition of arcade games and home-entertainment software that visitors may play. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. All activities are free with museum admission unless indicated otherwise. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today signed legislation that prohibits nursing homes from evicting people on Medicaid, as some have done in recent years as part of an effort to recruit more affluent patients. The bill, passed by Congress with bipartisan support, protects Medicaid patients who live in nursing homes that decide to withdraw from the program.

headline.main: Bill Protecting Medicaid Patients Is Signed

docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision that could make it easier for patients to bring malpractice suits against doctors in managed-care programs, New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that the widow of a man who died of a heart attack could sue her husband's primary-care doctor for failing to refer him quickly enough to a heart specialist. The Court of Appeals, in a unanimous decision, did not determine whether the primary-care physician was actually guilty of malpractice, leaving that to be decided by a jury in State Supreme Court in the Bronx. The Court of Appeals did rule, however, that a Federal law that had often blocked consumers from suing managed-care providers did not pre-empt the widow from suing her husband's doctor.

headline.main: Court Allows Lawsuit Against H.M.O. Doctor

docs.abstract: New York State Court of Appeals, in decision that could make it easier for patients to bring malpractice suits against doctors in managed-care programs, rules that widow of man who died of heart attack could sue her husband's primary-care doctor for failing to refer him quickly enough to heart specialist; lawsuit was brought by Susan Nealy, whose husband, Glenn, died in 1992; US Healthcare was his managed-care provider; Dr Ralph Yung was his primary-care physician (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have been investigating the possible misuse of millions of dollars of premiums paid to the collapsed HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, United States Attorney Faith Hochberg said in a letter to a legislator. Officials with the health company did not return telephone calls for comment.

headline.main: U.S. Attorney's Letter Confirms HIP Inquiry
